resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
nealrichardson commented on pull request #4491: ARROW-5505: [R] namespace cleanup
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4491
 
 
   This patch:
   
   * renames `array()` to `arrow_array()` and `table()` to `arrow_table()` to avoid collision with base R functions of the same name. AFAICT there are no callers out there of those functions (i.e. I checked `sparklyr` and I'm not aware of anything else depending on `arrow` in any way).
   * Prunes a trailing `-` from a test file name
   * Moves `crayon` and `vctrs` from Imports to Suggests, in response to a `R CMD CHECK` note. `crayon` was only used in one place in the package and makes sense to be optional; `vctrs` is only used in tests.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

romainfrancois commented on issue #4491: ARROW-5505: [R] namespace cleanup
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4491#issuecomment-500541116
 
 
   🤔 I understand the issue with masking the base package, but I'm not sure I like `arrow_array()` and `arrow_table()` for these factories, esp that other factories, e.g. `record_batch()` or `chunked_array()` presumably stay the same ?
   
   `vctrs` used to be more important earlier in the development, specifically when `array()` took `...` and `vctrs::vec_c()` would collapse the `...` into one vector. So yeah it's totally fine to move it to Suggests, perhaps we can even get rid of it for the tests. 
   
   We can totally just not use `crayon` at all. 
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

nealrichardson commented on issue #4491: ARROW-5505: [R] namespace cleanup
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4491#issuecomment-500545991
 
 
   Fair point, I worried about that too. My preference would be to namespace everything ([like sparklyr](https://spark.rstudio.com/reference/)), e.g. `arrow_record_batch`, rather than masking the base functions, but that was a bigger, more disruptive change so I wanted to try this. Happy to try that out if you're open to it--I think it also raises some design questions about how we want the R developer interface to Arrow to look and feel, which is a good thing to think about anyway.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

romainfrancois commented on issue #4491: ARROW-5505: [R] namespace cleanup
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4491#issuecomment-500755280
 
 
   Yeah, maybe it's worth have a broader discussion about the interface as a whole. These functions `array()`, `chunked_array()`, `table()`, and `record_batch()` are factories that make objects, maybe they should be e.g. : 
   
   `new_Array()`, `new_ChunkedArray()`, `new_Table()`, `new_RecordBatch()`
   
   Maybe the R6 classes should be made more user visible and then they would be e.g. 
   
   `Array$new()`, `ChunkedArray$new()`, `Table$new()`, `RecordBatch$new()` ...
   
   In any case, we should be consistent in what we do, and not just prefixing with `arrow_` for the cases where we do mask another function. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

romainfrancois commented on issue #5172: ARROW-5505: [R] Stop masking base R functions
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5172#issuecomment-527489188
 
 
   I get the need to not masking base functions and this is something we have come to regret in other projects. I was trying here to mimic the 🐍 interface (`pa.array()` ...) 
   
   `to_arrow()` feels vague, maybe we could do some sort of namespacing, e.g. `arrow_array()` or something, but then we would kind of have to do it for all functions :/

users@infra.apache.org

nealrichardson commented on pull request #5279: WIP ARROW-5505: [R] Stop masking base R functions (draft 3)
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5279
 
 
   @romainfrancois Looking back at previous discussion on the array/table issue, I saw https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4491#issuecomment-500755280 and thought I'd give it a try with the R6 constructors. I only did it for Array here but if you're interested I can take it further (just didn't want to sink more time into it if you 👎 already). Summary: `"arrow::Array"` class is replaced with `Array`, `array()` is replaced with `Array$create()`, and lots of backticks are deleted.
   
   As I was thinking about it, your discomfort that `to_arrow()` seemed too magical is right, but it's fine as long as there's also a more direct/less magical way to create the Arrow objects. And using the R6 classes seems like a natural way to provide the lower-level interface. 
   
   Unfortunately, I didn't see a good way to do the magical subclassing that `Array$dispatch` does currently (i.e. let you call Array$new() and get a StructArray back if that was the appropriate type), so I had to create a separate `$create()` class method rather than use the general `$new()` (I've done the subclassing magic with S4 previously, but the R6 docs are thin when it comes to these more advanced topics.) Maybe you know better. 
   
   More broadly, I'd view this as part of a larger removal of backticks and prefixes throughout the class names, which is a good thing IMO. The current classes don't lend themselves to being invoked directly because of the backticks and colons in the names. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description: The package startup message about masking base functions can be scary. We should avoid masking base functions without a compelling reason (i.e. let's do arrow_array() instead of array(), arrow_table()). The arrow versions do very different things than the base functions; plus, end users shouldn’t be dealing directly with Tables and Arrays, so they don’t need to figure so prominently in the public API of the package.
fields.summary: [R] Stop masking base R functions/rethink namespacing

comments.body: PR [https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4491] aborted pending further design but see the discussion there for ideas.
